stem: A client with HELLP syndrome is being prepared for an emergent C-section. Based on the documentation, which finding indicates the transition from HELLP to Disseminated Intravascular Coagulation (DIC)?

options.text: Low fibrinogen (110 mg/dL) and oozing from the IV site.

rationale.correct: The documentation shows a transition from HELLP to Disseminated Intravascular Coagulation (DIC) (a1). While low platelets are expected in HELLP, a low fibrinogen level (110 mg/dL) and prolonged clotting times (PT/PTT) are definitive for DIC. DIC is a consumptive coagulopathy where all the clotting factors and fibrinogen are 'used up,' leading to bleeding from everywhere (IV site, gums, bladder). The high D-dimer confirms massive clot breakdown occurring simultaneously.
clinicalPearls: In simple HELLP, clotting times (PT/PTT) and fibrinogen are usually NORMAL.
DIC = Bleeding from every orifice/puncture site.
Treatment involves replacing factors (FFP), Fibrinogen (Cryoprecipitate), and Platelets while treating the 'Trigger' (delivering the baby/placenta).

questionTrap.howToOvercome: Platelets are low in HELLP *without* DIC. To 'diagnose' DIC in an NCLEX question, you MUST see Prolonged PT/PTT or Low Fibrinogen or Bleeding from IV sites.

mnemonic.title: D-I-C
mnemonic.expansion: D-Death. I-Is. C-Coming (unless you fix the clotting factors fast).

exhibits.content: Current: Oozing noted from the IV site and from the gums after mouth care. Small petechiae and purpura noted on the client's trunk. Urine in the Foley catheter is dark red.

exhibits.title: Medical Context
exhibits.content: Complication Note: HELLP syndrome is a trigger for DIC in 15-20% of severe cases due to tissue factor release from the liver and placenta.
